docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Nov. 27 front-page article ''Employees Facing Steep Increases in Health Costs'' raises the deeper issue of whether employers are useful intermediaries in buying health insurance for workers. If they cannot control costs, what value do they add?
docs.abstract: Dwight McNeill letter asks whether employers are useful intermediariers in purchasing health insurance for workers if they are not able to control costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With more than 200 people complaining each year that they had been illegally denied emergency care by hospitals, the Clinton Administration told hospitals that they must examine and stabilize patients without any delays to ask about insurance coverage.
docs.snippet: With more than 200 people complaining each year that they had been illegally denied emergency care by hospitals, the Clinton Administration told hospitals that they must examine and stabilize patients without any delays to ask about insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: Yielding to a stream of complaints from patients who say they were illegally denied emergency care, the Clinton Administration told hospitals today that they must examine and stabilize patients without any delays to ask about insurance coverage. A 1986 law prohibits hospitals from rejecting or ''dumping'' patients who request care in emergency rooms and also prohibits them from delaying care to check on insurance coverage. But with the rise of managed care, consumer advocates and Federal officials say, hospitals sometimes delay examining or treating patients until they get approval from health maintenance organizations.

headline.main: Hospitals Told Not to Delay Emergency Room Treatment

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration warns hospitals that they must examine and stabilize patients without any delays to ask about insurance coverage; 1986 law prohibits hospitals from rejecting patients who request care in emeregency rooms and also prohibits them from delaying care to check on insurance coverage; consumer advocates and Federal officials say that with rise of managed care, hospitals sometimes delay examining or treating patients until they get approval from health maintenance organizations; say law has been aggressively enforced only in past two years, after Congress provided more money to Health and Human Services and Justice departments to investigate complaints (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Separatists Maintain A Hold on Power in Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard and the separatist Parti Quebecois managed to retain their control of Quebec. With nearly all polling stations reporting, the separatist party had 44.3 percent of the vote, compared with 42.8 percent for the anti-separtist Quebec Liberal Party and 12 percent for a third party, Democratic Action. A1
